list.title: Question 1
list.content:
In this question give all angles in radians.
Let $z=1+2i$ and
$w=4+i$.


Find $z+w$. [1]



Find:


$∣z+w∣$;


$arg(z+w)$. [2]





Find $θ$, the angle shown on the diagram below. [2]

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Let $z=2+i$ and
$w=1−2i$.


Find $zw$. [2]



Illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram. [3]



Let $θ$ be the angle between $zw$ and $w$. Find $θ$,
giving your answer in radians.[2]
list.markScheme:
The product of $z$ and $w$ is
$$$zw​=(2+i)(1−2i)=2−4i+i+2=4−3i​​$$$


If we illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram, we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ce332d8e-4a39-41c6-929d-bcab05130838/images/e0dad541-eddc-48d6-bc66-b3dc162fa6c1/96f14dbc4defd6873946ae02a45c2e643f791342.svg)




We have
$$$argw​=tan−1((−2)/1)=−1.107148…​$$$
and
$$$argzw​=tan−1((−3)/4)=−0.643501…​$$$
Hence we get
$$$θ​=∣argw∣−∣argzw∣=(1.107148…)−(0.643501…)≈0.464​​$$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The complex numbers $z$ and $w$ correspond to the points A and B as
shown on the diagram below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f49c4a4e-a8b9-40a0-9883-70b2dab8b609/images/f51352cb-3ef3-4ded-8d97-25718787a7a9/0c46fa70e78de8ef6fa11a8d28566cc1742d4a83.svg)




Find the exact value of $∣z−w∣$. [2]





Find the exact perimeter of triangle AOB.


Find the exact area of triangle AOB. [4]
list.markScheme:
Using the cosine rule, we get
$$$∣z−w∣2∣z−w∣2∣z−w∣2​=∣z∣2+∣w∣2−2∣z∣∣w∣cos(6π​)=52+52−2(5)(5)[23​​]=25(2−3​)​$$$
$$$∣z−w∣=52−3​​​$$$




The exact perimeter of triangle AOB is
$$$perimeter​=∣z∣+∣w∣+∣z−w∣=5+5+52−3​​=10+52−3​​​​$$$


The exact area of triangle AOB is
$$$area​=21​∣z∣∣w∣sin(6π​)=21​(5)(5)[21​]=425​​​$$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let
$z1​=23​cis(127π​)$,
$z3​=2cisθ$, and $z2​=z1​+z3​$ be
represented by the points
A, B and C on an Argand diagram as shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/0085c6d0-51f3-4387-8aec-3a391223c6f4/f4ed9162ce8f5fbe06e47de0f00519455d24ad0d.svg)


The shape OABC is a rectangle.


Show that $θ=12π​$.
[1]



Find $arg(z1​−z2​)$. [1]



Express $z2​$ in modulus-argument form. [4]
list.markScheme:
From the diagram, we find
$$$θ​=argz1​−AOˆC=127π​−2π​=12π​​​$$$


If we illustrate $z1​−z2​$ on the same Argand diagram, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/04442292-e044-4715-9411-67fdf5174007/61b40c253f2d12de7c4ab40eafed5e3eb9ac59d0.svg)


Hence the argument of $z1​−z2​$ is
$$$arg(z1​−z2​)​=COˆD−argz3​=π−12π​=−1211π​​​$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/04442292-e044-4715-9411-67fdf5174007/61b40c253f2d12de7c4ab40eafed5e3eb9ac59d0.svg)




Using the right triangle OBC, we get
$$$∣z2​∣2∣z2​∣2∣z2​∣2∣z2​∣​=∣z1​∣2+∣z3​∣2=(23​)2+22=16=4​$$$
Using the right triangle OBC again, we have
$$$cos(BOˆC)cos(BOˆC)BOˆC​=∣z2​∣∣z3​∣​=42​(=21​)=3π​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$argz2​​=argz3​+BOˆC=12π​+3π​=125π​​$$$
Hence, if we write $z2​$ in
modulus-argument form, we obtain
$$$z2​=4cis(125π​)​​$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A circle is drawn on an Argand diagram as shown below. The tangent to
the circle from the point B$(0,9)$ meets the circle at the point A as
shown. Let $w=OA$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a933f476-df41-4384-9ff1-38ce595a983f/images/a7e2f81c-7176-46a6-9367-c80340035fc4/756bc10d49856365edc8188e18631d432452e02d.svg)




Show that $∣w∣=33​$. [2]



Find $argw$. [2]



Hence write $w$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$. [2]
list.markScheme:
We have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a933f476-df41-4384-9ff1-38ce595a983f/images/5eb70fb9-568d-4a68-b0f3-a7ba593cbbc1/be4795ddca85773f31f1a7dd616d51f34bbef9b7.svg)


Using the right triangle ABC, we find
$$$cos(ACˆB)ACˆBACˆO​=63​(=21​)=3π​=32π​​$$$
Hence, using the
cosine rule, we get
$$$∣w∣2∣w∣2∣w∣2​=32+32−2(3)(3)cos(32π​)=18−18[−21​]=27​$$$
$$$∣w∣=33​​​$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a933f476-df41-4384-9ff1-38ce595a983f/images/5eb70fb9-568d-4a68-b0f3-a7ba593cbbc1/be4795ddca85773f31f1a7dd616d51f34bbef9b7.svg)




Using the isosceles triangle OAC, we have
$$$AOˆC​=21​(π−ACˆO)=21​[π−32π​]=6π​​$$$
Hence the argument of $w$ is
$$$argw​=2π​−AOˆC=2π​−6π​=3π​​​$$$


If we write $w$ in Cartesian form, we obtain
$$$w​=33​cis(3π​)=33​[cos(3π​)+isin(3π​)]=33​[21​+i23​​]=233​​+29​i​​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Consider the complex number $z$, such that $z=2eaπ​i$, where $∣a∣>1,a∈R$.

Show that $z$ can never be a positive real number. 	[2]


Now consider the complex number $w$, such that $w=−2​+2​i$. There is one value of $a$ such that $wz​$ is a positive real number.

Find this value of $a$. [6]
list.markScheme:
For $z$ to be a positive real number, the argument of $z$ must be a multiple of $2π$. The argument of $z$ is $aπ​$. We have
$$$aπ​aa​=2πk,k∈Z=2πkπ​=2k1​​M1A1​$$$
Given that $k∈Z$, $∣a∣<1$. But we have been given that $∣a∣>1$.
$$$​Therefore, z can never be a positive real number.​​AG​$$$


Let's write $w$ in exponential form. The following Argand diagram shows $w$ geometrically:


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59d736c0-c18b-4091-88f3-cee089df7548/images/0e8a0ff9-560c-4903-85ff-04d803a38478/1184a.JPG)


The modulus of $w$ is $2$ and the argument of $w$ is $43π​$.
Hence, $w=2e43π​i$.
$$$​(A1)$$$
We have
$$$wz​​=2e43π​i2eaπ​i​=(eaπ​i)(e−43π​i)[am1​=a−m]=e(aπ​−43π​)i[am×an=am+n]​$$$
For $wz​$ to be a positive real number, the argument of $w$ must be a multiple of $2π$. The argument of $wz​$ is $aπ​−43π​$.
$$$​(A1)$$$
We have
$$$aπ​−43π​a1​−43​4a4−3a​4−3a44a​=2πk,k∈Z=2k=2k=8ak=8ak+3a=a(8k+3)=8k+34​​(M1)(A1)​$$$
Recall that $∣a∣>1$. If we consider that $k$ must be an integer, we can say the following:

If $k≥1$, then $0<a<1$.
If $k≤−1$, then $−1<a<0$.

$$$​(R1)$$$
Therefore the only possible integer value for $k$ is $k=0$ and hence $a=34​​$
$$$​A1$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
On an Argand diagram, the complex numbers
$z1​=2+23​i$,
$z2​=1−i$ and $z3​=z1​z2​$ are
represented by the vertices of a triangle.
Find the area of the triangle.
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$∣z1​∣∣z2​∣​=22+(23​)2​=4=12+(−1)2​=2​​$$$
and
$$$argz1​argz2​​=tan−1(23​/2)=60°=tan−1(−1/1)=−45°​$$$
Hence, using the property of modulus, we get
$$$∣z3​∣​=∣z1​z2​∣=∣z1​∣∣z2​∣=42​​$$$
and
$$$argz3​​=arg(z1​z3​)=argz1​+argz2​=15°​$$$
If we sketch the triangle whose vertices
represent $z1​$, $z2​$ and $z3​$ on an Argand diagram, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d9540a91-3a6d-402f-96f6-82e7e2baf51e/images/357aebcc-946f-48d1-9cb4-5216d45536d4/cce5162c3d61fa13f25a6e2323562142371b3997.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is
$$$area(ABˆC)​=area(AOˆC)+area(BOˆC)−area(AOˆB)=21​(4)(42​)sin45°+21​(2​)(42​)sin60°−21​(4)(2​)sin105°≈8.73​​$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Consider two sinusoidal functions with the same period, $S1​$ and $S2​$, given by
$$$S1​=8cos(bx−30∘)andS2​=6cos(bx+30∘)​$$$
The two sinusoidal functions are combined to make the equation $S1​+S2​=Acos(bx+α)$.
Find the value of $A$ and the value of $α$.
list.markScheme:
First, converting to radians, we have
$$$S1​=8cos(bx−6π​)andS2​=6cos(bx+6π​)​$$$
Next, we note that $S1​$ is the real part of the complex number $z1​=8cis(bx−6π​)$, and $S2​$ is the real part of the complex number $z2​=6cis(bx+6π​)$.
Therefore $S1​+S2​$ is the real part of $z1​+z2​$. We have
$$$z1​+z2​z1​+z2​​=8cis(bx−6π​)+6cis(bx+6π​)=8e(bx−6π​)i+6e(bx+6π​)i[converting to exponential form]=8ebxi−6π​i+6ebxi+6π​i=8ebxi⋅e−6π​i+6ebxi⋅e6π​i[am+n=am⋅an]=ebxi(8e−6π​i+6e6π​i)=ebxi(12.17e−0.08229i)[using G.D.C.]=12.17ebxi−0.08229i[am⋅an=am+n]=12.17e(bx−0.08229)i​(M1)(M1)(M1)​$$$
Returning to polar form we have $z1​+z2​=12.17cis(bx−0.08229)$.
The real part of $z1​+z2​$ is $12.17cos(bx−0.08229)$. Converting back to degrees from radians, we have
$$$​(M1)$$$
$$$S1​+S2​​=12.17cos(bx−4.715∘)​$$$
$A≈12.2 and α≈−4.72∘​$
$$$​A1$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Consider two power sources with voltages $V1​$ and $V2​$ respectively, where $ω$ is the frequency of the power source in Hertz (Hz) and $t$ is time in seconds.
It is given that
$$$V1​=161sin(ωt+1.047).​$$$
When the two power sources are combined, the resultant voltage $V1​+V2​$ is given by
$$$VT​=240sin(ωt+1.883).​$$$


Find $V2​$. Give your answer in the form $asin(ωt+b)$, where $a,b∈R$.[6]



Hence, determine the difference in phase shift between $V1​$ and $V2​$.[2]
list.markScheme:
When adding sinusoidal functions, writing the functions in Euler's form makes sense as it allows use to easily add and subtract them.
$V1​$ is the imaginary part of the complex number $z1​$ such that
$$$z1​​=161(cos(ωt+1.047)+isin(ωt+1.047))=161ei(ωt+1.047)​$$$
And $VT​$ is the imaginary part of the complex number $z2​$ such that
$$$z2​​=240(cos(ωt+1.883)+isin(ωt+1.883))=240ei(ωt+1.883)​$$$
Given that $V2​=VT​−V1​$, $V2​$ is the imaginary part of $z2​−z1​$. We have
$$$z2​−z1​​=240ei(ωt+1.883)−161ei(ωt+1.047)=240(eiωt)(e1.883i)−161(eiωt)(e1.047i)=eiωt(240e1.883i−161e1.047i)=eiωt(178.1e2.618i)[by G.D.C.]=178ei(ωt+2.62)​$$$
Converting to polar form, we have
$$$V2​​=Im(178(cos(ωt+2.62)+isin(ωt+2.62)))V2​=178sin(ωt+2.62)​​$$$


The phase shift of $V1​$ is $1.047$ and the phase shift of $V2​$ is $2.62$. Hence the difference is given by
$$$2.62−1.047≈1.57​​$$$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Let
$z=2​cis(83π​)$
and
$w=2cis(24nπ​)$ ,
where $n∈Z+$.


Find the value of $z6$. Give your answer in the form
$reiθ$, where
$r≥0$, $−π<θ≤π$. [2]



Find the value of $(wz)4$ for $n=5$. Give your answer in the form
$reiθ$, where
$r≥0$, $−π<θ≤π$. [3]



Find the smallest integer $n>9$ such that
$wz​∈R$. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$zw​=2​ei83π​=2ei24nπ​​$$$


Therefore
$$$z6​=(2​ei83π​)6=8ei49π​=8ei(49π​−2π)[so that −π<θ≤π]z6=8ei4π​​​$$$


We have
$$$(wz)4​=[(2ei245π​)(2​ei83π​)]4[for n=5]=[22​ei(245π​+83π​)]4=(22​ei127π​)4=64ei37π​=64ei(37π​−2π)[so that −π<θ≤π](wz)4=64ei3π​​​$$$


The quotient $wz​$ is a real number when
$arg(wz​)$ is a multiple of $π$.
We have
$$$wz​arg(wz​)​=2ei24nπ​2​ei83π​​=22​​ei(83π​−24nπ​)=22​​ei(249−n​)π=(249−n​)π​$$$
Therefore the smallest integer $n>9$ such that
$wz​∈R$ is
$n=33​$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Two voltage sources are connected to a circuit. At time $t$ milliseconds
(ms), the voltage from the first source is $V1​(t)=12cos(20t)$ and
the voltage from the second source is $V2​(t)=18cos(20t+5)$, where
both $V1​(t)$ and $V2​(t)$ are measured in
volts.


Write, in the form $V(t)=Acos(ωt+φ)$,
an expression for the total voltage in the circuit at time $t$ ms.
[4]



Hence write down the highest voltage in the circuit. [1]
list.markScheme:
The total voltage in the circuit at time $t$ ms is given by
$V(t)=V1​(t)+V2​(t)$.
Hence we have
$$$V(t)​=12cos(20t)+18cos(20t+5)=Re[12cis(20t)+18cis(20t+5)]=Re[12ei20t+18ei(20t+5)]​$$$
Hence we further have
$$$12ei20t+18ei(20t+5)​=ei20t[12+18ei5]≈ei20t[17.1−17.3i][by using G.D.C.]≈ei20t[24.3e−i0.790][by using G.D.C.]≈24.3ei(20t−0.790)​$$$
Hence we get
$$$V(t)​≈Re[24.3ei(20t−0.790)]≈24.3cos(20t−0.790)​​$$$


Hence the highest voltage in the circuit is
$24.3volts​$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
The sunset time in Paris can be modelled by the function
$$$S(t)=1.85sin(0.52t−1.57)+19.5$$$
where $t$ is time in months, from the beginning of January.
The sunrise time can similarly be modelled by
$$$R(t)=1.35sin(0.52t−4.7)+7.5$$$
Both $S(t)$ and $R(t)$ are measured in hours since midnight.
$S(t)$ can be expressed as $im(z1​)+19.5$ and $R(t)$ can be expressed as $im(z2​)+7.5$, where $z1​,z2​∈C$.

Write down expressions for $z1​$ and $z2​$. Give your answers in the form $z1,2​=reθi$.[2]


The number of daylight hours in Paris, $D(t)$, is given by $D(t)=S(t)−R(t)$.


Hence show that the number of hours of daylight in Paris can be modelled by the function
$$$D(t)=3.20sin(0.52t−1.57)+12$$$
[6]



According to the model, find:


the highest number of hours of daylight in a year;


The approximate number of months per year in which there is at least 14 hours of daylight. [5]
list.markScheme:
Equating our function $S(t)$ to $im(z1​)+19.5$, we must have
$$$im(z1​)​=1.85sin(0.52t−1.57)​$$$
This is the imaginary part of the complex number
$$$z1​​=1.85cos(0.52t−1.57)+i(1.85sin(0.52t−1.57))​$$$
In the required form, we have $z1​=1.85e(0.52t−1.57)i​$
$$$​A1$$$
Using similar reasoning with $R(t)$, we have $z2​=1.35e(0.52t−4.7)i​$
$$$​A1$$$


We have
$$$D(t)​=S(t)−R(t)=im(z1​)+19.5−(im(z2​)+7.5)=im(z1​)−im(z2​)+12=im(z1​−z2​)+12​(A1)​$$$
Let's find $z1​−z2​$ so that we can identify the imaginary part.
$$$z1​−z2​​=1.85e(0.52t−1.57)i−1.35e(0.52t−4.7)i=1.85e0.52ti−1.57i−1.35e0.52ti−4.7i=1.85(e0.52ti)(e−1.57i)−1.35(e0.52ti)(e−4.7i)=e0.52ti(1.85e−1.57i−1.35e−4.7i)​(M1)(M1)​$$$
We have now factorised the variable $t$ out of the brackets, allowing us to compute a single complex number inside the brackets.
$$$z1​−z2​​=e0.52ti(3.199...e−1.565...i)[by G.D.C.]=3.199...e0.52ti−1.565...i=3.199...e(0.52t−1.565...)i=3.20e(0.52t−1.57)i(3 s.f.)​(M1)(A1)​$$$
Hence we get
$$$D(t)​=im[3.20e(0.52t−1.57)i]+12=3.20sin(0.52t−1.57)+12​​A1​$$$



According to the model, the highest number of hours of daylight is

$$$Dmax​​=3.20+12=15.2 hours​​M1A1​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=D(t)$, and also the graph of $y=14$ [by using G.D.C.], we can find the points of intersection. Our solution is the domain for which $D(t)>14$.
$$$​(M1)$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1c4bb223-a0f1-43f6-8a5f-86def982cb52/images/702081d9-df01-40f0-808a-189c4ef5d798/complex.JPG)


We have
$$$7.762...−4.317...​=3.444...​(M1)​$$$
There are at least 14 hours of daylight for approximately $3.44 months​$ of the year.
$$$​A1$$$
$Note: An answer of 3 months is acceptable.$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Ali is swimming in a public pool with some of his friends. At time $t$
seconds, he $encounters$ some waves with height
$h1​(t)=0.15sin(3t)$ from big Bobby jumping into the
pool, and waves of height $h2​(t)=0.08sin(3t+1.25)$
from small Suzie jumping into the pool. Both $h1​(t)$ and $h2​(t)$ are
measured in metres.


Write, in the form $h(t)=Asin(ωt+φ)$,
an expression for the total height of the waves Ali encounters at
time $t$ seconds. [3]



Find the times in the first $5$ seconds when Ali isn't affected by
any waves. [2]



Find the first time when the waves reaching Ali has maximum height.
[1]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$h(t)​=h1​(t)+h2​(t)=0.15sin(3t)+0.08sin(3t+1.25)=Im[0.15cis(3t)+0.08cis(3t+1.25)]=Im[0.15ei3t+0.08ei(3t+1.25)]​$$$
Hence we further have
$$$0.15ei3t+0.08ei(3t+1.25)​=ei3t[0.15+0.08ei1.25]≈ei3t[0.175+0.0759i][by using G.D.C.]≈ei3t[0.191ei0.409][by using G.D.C.]≈0.191ei(3t+0.409)​$$$
Hence we find
$$$h(t)​≈Im[0.191ei(3t+0.409)]≈0.191sin(3t+0.409)​​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=h(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cbd4564-0681-4f42-b214-d4d91937919a/images/2b870085-23f9-4c2a-bcb0-7dbf9029b430/c1274d3811929d9ce0da7917e348fa7728bfc3fe.svg)


Hence the times in the first $5$ seconds when Ali isn't affected by
any waves are
$$$0.911s,1.96s,3.01s,4.05s​​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=h(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cbd4564-0681-4f42-b214-d4d91937919a/images/91489501-8a21-4124-adbb-cc1a63b0c90e/ffc02fbfbe87991fd09c664afe4f4f0a2e6d0e8d.svg)


Hence the first time when the wave reaching Ali has max height is at
$0.387s​$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
In an unbalanced three-phase electrical circuit, the current at time $t$
ms is given by
$I(t)=2sin(5t)+5sin(5t−43π​)+10sin(5t−45π​)$,
where $I(t)$ is measured in milliamperes (mA).


Write $I(t)$ in the form $Acos(ωt+φ)$.
[4]



Hence find the highest current flowing through the circuit, and the
time it first occurs. [2]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$I(t)​=2sin(5t)+5sin(5t−43π​)+10sin(5t−45π​)=Im[2cis(5t)+5cis(5t−43π​)+10cis(5t−45π​)]=Im[2ei5t+5ei(5t−43π​)+10ei(5t−45π​)](1)​$$$
Hence we further have
$$$2ei5t+5ei(5t−43π​)+10ei(5t−45π​)​=ei5t[2+5e−i43π​+10e−i45π​]≈ei5t[−8.61+3.54i][by using G.D.C.]≈ei5t[9.30ei2.75][by using G.D.C.]≈9.30ei(5t+2.75)(2)​$$$
Hence, using the identity
$sinθ=cos(θ−2π​)$ with
$θ=5t+2.75$, we get
$$$I(t)​≈Im[9.30ei(5t+2.75)][by (1) and (2)]≈9.30sin(5t+2.75)≈9.30cos(5t+1.18)​[since 2.75−2π​≈1.18]​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=I(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b19fb021-405d-4f87-861f-57db50190a0c/images/826559f4-1052-4b95-9c53-4601db6b6fc2/edddcb5f4484a3ee01b2a7e1928a31daa1879cc9.svg)


Hence the highest current is
$9.30mA​$
and the
$1$st time it $occurs$ is at  $1.02ms​$
